metadata.case_name: Tata Iron and Steel Co., Ltd. v. Commercial Tax Officer, Lyons Range, Calcutta and others

facts.text: The company has its registered office in Bombay, Head Sales office in Calcutta in West Bengal, and factories in Jamshedpur in Bihar.
The company is registered as a dealer under the Bihar Sales Tax Act and under the Central Sales Tax Act in West Bengal.

For assessment period July 1, 1957 to March 31, 1958, company submitted return to Commercial Tax Officer (CTO), Lyons Range, Calcutta, disclosing gross taxable turnover of Rs. 9,561.71 nP. for sales liable to Central sales tax in West Bengal.

By memorandum dated August 12, 1959, CTO directed company to submit statement of sales from Jamshedpur where documents were transferred in West Bengal or other sales under s.3(b) of Central Sales Tax Act, 1956.

Company by letter dated September 30, 1959, informed CTO that requisition was without jurisdiction; contended all sales from Jamshedpur under s.3(a), situs in Bihar; even s.3(b) sales assessed where sale takes place per s.4(2).
CTO by order dated October 21, 1959, made best judgment assessment on gross turnover of Rs. 9,00,09,561.71 nP., demanded Rs. 41,14,718.12 nP. as tax.

Company filed returns for same period with Sales Tax Officer, Jamshedpur and Dhanbad (Bihar), including all inter-State sales from Bihar exceeding Rs. 26 crores, paid Rs. 71 lakhs as advance tax under Central Sales Tax Act.
Company filed petition under Art.32 for certiorari quashing assessment order and mandamus restraining enforcement.
CTO observed sales under s.3(b) taxable in West Bengal if documents physically transferred there, even if consigned to self.

legal_issues.text: Whether the petition under Art.32 is maintainable as no fundamental right infringed since vires of Central Sales Tax Act not challenged.

Whether West Bengal CTO has jurisdiction to assess and levy Central Sales Tax on inter-State sales of steel goods from Jamshedpur (Bihar) where documents of title transferred in West Bengal under s.3(b).
Interpretation of s.3(a) and s.3(b) of Central Sales Tax Act: whether mutually exclusive; what constitutes sale under each.
Which is the 'appropriate State' for s.3(b) sales: where documents transferred or per s.4(2); place where sale 'effected'.

petitioner_arguments.text: All sales from Jamshedpur under s.3(a); even if some s.3(b), appropriate State is where sale takes place per s.4(2), goods in Bihar at contract or appropriation; filed returns and paid tax in Bihar.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Central Sales Tax Act ss.3(a), 3(b), 4(2); single liability to tax.

petitioner_arguments.text: Threat of double taxation infringes fundamental rights under Art.19(1)(f) and (g).

respondent_arguments.text: Petition not maintainable under Art.32 as no fundamental right violated; vires not challenged; remedy under WB Sales Tax Act.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Ramji Lal v. ITO; Laxmanappa v. Union of India; Art.265 not fundamental right.

respondent_arguments.text: s.3(b) sales where documents of title transferred (physically or endorsed) in West Bengal during movement from Bihar; WB appropriate State as place where sale effected.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Central Sales Tax Act ss.2(a) Expl.II, 3(b), 9.

respondent_arguments.text: s.4(2) not applicable to inter-State sales; independent of s.3.

court_reasoning.text: Petition maintainable under Art.32 as double taxation threat (paid in Bihar) infringes Art.19(1)(g); distinguished Ramji Lal etc.; followed Bengal Immunity etc.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Single liability under CST Act; prima facie infringement.

court_reasoning.text: s.3(a) and (b) mutually exclusive to avoid double tax; s.3(a): movement occasioned by contract of sale (property passes in either state); s.3(b): property passes by transfer of documents during movement.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Clauses cover different sales; overlap excluded by making s.3(b) prevail where applicable.

court_reasoning.text: For s.3(b), 'appropriate State' is where sale 'effected' i.e. where documents of title transferred passing property (s.2(a) Expl. cl.ii); not merely physical delivery without agreement to pass property.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Sale effected where transfer of documents completes passing of property.

court_reasoning.text: s.4(2) formulates situs for non-inter-State sales (outside State/import/export per Arts.286,269); subject to s.3; not explanatory of s.2(a) Expl.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Chapter II headings and constitutional basis distinguish.

court_reasoning.text: CTO erred: assumed all sales to WB parties s.3(b); physical transfer without endorsement/delivery per mercantile practice not necessarily pass property; did not verify movement during transfer or situs per s.4(2) if applicable.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Error apparent on face; best judgment invalid.

holdings.text: Art.32 petition maintainable against unauthorised double levy even if Act valid.

s.3(a): sale occasions movement from one State to another by contract terms, property passes otherwise than by documents during movement. s.3(b): property passes by transfer of documents during movement.
Appropriate State for s.3(b): State where sale effected i.e. documents transferred passing property.
s.4(2) applies to determine situs of sales not inter-State (outside State etc.).

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Bombay v. United Motors (India) Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Art.286 interpretation; situs of sale; multiple taxation.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bengal Immunity Co. Ltd. v. State of Bihar
precedents_cited.relevance: Art.286 parts independent; Explanation deems inter-State to intra-State.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ram Narain Sons Ltd. v. Asst. Commr. of Sales Tax

precedents_cited.relevance: Art.265 not fundamental right enforceable under Art.32.

Kailash Nath v. State of UP
precedents_cited.relevance: Illegal levy under valid Act infringes Art.19(1)(g).

statutes_cited.relevance: Defines inter-State sales; appropriate State; levy/collection; situs rules.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Fundamental rights; tax without authority; inter-State trade restrictions.

outcome.summary: Assessment order dated October 21, 1959 quashed/set aside as CTO failed to apply correct tests for s.3(b) sales (movement during transfer; property passing by transfer); liberty to reassess applying proper interpretation of ss.2(a),3(b),4(2). Shah J: company costs; Sarkar J: no costs order.
outcome.relief_granted: Writ of certiorari quashing assessment; liberty to reassess.
outcome.costs: Company entitled to costs (Shah J.); no order as to costs (Sarkar J.).

key_quotes.text: "Under the Central Sales Tax Act, there is a single liability to pay tax on inter-State sales."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Basis for Art.32 maintainability and mutual exclusivity of s.3 clauses.

key_quotes.text: A sale under s.3(b) "is effected by transfer of documents of title to the goods during their movement from one State to another."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The place where the transfer of documents of title takes place, is the place where the sale is effected."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The Commercial Tax Officer has failed to apply the correct tests and has made assumptions which are not warranted."
key_quotes.speaker: court
